headline: Pathogenicity-associated gene shows dramatic upregulation during wheat infection
one_paragraph_summary:
This gene exhibits extraordinary upregulation during pathogenic processes in Fusarium graminearum, with expression levels reaching >1,900-fold increases during wheat infection compared to vegetative growth.
  • Shows highest expression during active infection and disease progression in wheat
  • Demonstrates preferential upregulation on dead plant tissue compared to live tissue (>150-fold difference)
  • Expression correlates with symptom development and pathogenicity
  • Remains silent or minimally expressed during vegetative growth, conidiation, and stress conditions
The dramatic infection-specific expression pattern and consistent ranking in the >99th percentile during pathogenic conditions strongly suggests this gene encodes a critical pathogenicity factor essential for F. graminearum's ability to colonize and cause disease in cereal hosts.

topics.headline: Massive upregulation during wheat infection with progressive increase over time
topics.one_sentence_summary: Expression increases dramatically during wheat infection, reaching >1,900-fold upregulation at 6 days post-inoculation and showing progressive increases from 24-192 hours, consistently ranking in the >99th percentile.

topics.headline: Strong preference for dead plant tissue and correlation with disease symptoms
topics.one_sentence_summary: Gene shows >150-fold higher expression on dead wheat tissue compared to live tissue and demonstrates a clear gradient of expression that correlates with disease progression from symptomless to fully symptomatic infection.

topics.headline: Progressive upregulation during maize stalk infection over extended timeframe
topics.one_sentence_summary: Expression doubles from early (12-18 hours) to late timepoints (144 hours) during maize stalk infection, reaching the 91st percentile and suggesting importance in later stages of pathogenesis.
